file_name: Lecture 11 - Programming on GPUs - Part 1 - Slides (Lec-11-GPU).pdf

segments.content:
Lecture 11: Programming on GPUs 
(Part 1)
1

Overview
‚Ä¢ GPGPU: General purpose computation using 
graphics processing units (GPUs) and graphics API 
‚Ä¢ GPU consists of multiprocessor element that run 
under the shared-memory threads model. GPUs can 
run hundreds or thousands of threads in parallel and 
has its own DRAM. 
‚Äì GPU is a dedicated, multithread, data parallel processor.
‚Äì GPU is good at 
‚Ä¢ Data-parallel processing: the same computation executed on 
many data elements in parallel
‚Ä¢ with high arithmetic intensity 
2

‚Ä¢ Performance history: GPUs are much faster than CPUs
3
AMD FireStream 9250: 1Tflops

‚Ä¢ CUDA: Compute unified device architecture
‚Äì A new hardware and software architecture for 
issuing and managing computations on the GPU
‚Ä¢ CUDA C is a programming language developed 
by NVIDIA for programming on their GPUs. It 
is an extension of C. 
5

nVidia GPU Architecture
‚Ä¢ Many processors are striped together
‚Ä¢ Small, fast shared memory 6

Hardware Overview
‚Ä¢ Basic building block is a ‚Äústreaming 
multiprocessor‚Äù (SM) with:
‚Äì 32 cores, each with 1024 registers
‚Äì up to 48 threads per core
‚Äì 64KB of shared memory / L1 cache
‚Äì 8KB cache for constants held in device memory
‚Ä¢ C2050: 14 SMs, 3/6 GB memory
8

GPU Computing at CRC
‚Ä¢ http://wiki.crc.nd.edu/wiki/index.php/Developmental_Systems
‚Ä¢ gpu1.crc.nd.edu
‚Ä¢ gpu2.crc.nd.edu
‚Ä¢ gpu3.crc.nd.edu
‚Ä¢ gpu4.crc.nd.edu
‚Ä¢ gpu5.crc.nd.edu
‚Ä¢ CUDA compiler is nvcc
‚Ä¢ To compile and run GPU code:
‚Äì module load cuda
‚Äì module show cuda
‚Äì nvcc hello.cu 
9

Heterogeneous Computing
‚Ä¢ Host: The CPU and its memory (host memory)
‚Ä¢ Device: The GPU and its memory (device memory)
10
Things to learn:
1. Write code for the host and code for the device
2. Run device code from the host
3. Use device memory (transfer data between host and device)

CUDA Concepts and Terminology
mykernel<<<1,1>>>();
‚Ä¢ Kernel: a C function which is flagged to be run on a 
GPU (or a device).
‚Ä¢ Triple angle brackets mark a call from host code to 
device code
‚Äì Also called a ‚Äúkernel launch‚Äù
‚Äì The parameters (1,1) will be explained in a moment
12

‚Ä¢ add() runs on the device, so device_c must point to 
the device memory
‚Äì This is why we call cudaMalloc() to allocate memory on 
the device
‚Ä¢ Do not deference the pointer returned by 
cudaMalloc() from code that executes on the host. 
Host code may pass this pointer around, perform 
arithmetic on it. But we can not use it to read or 
write from memory.
‚Äì Its C equivalent is malloc().
‚Ä¢ We can access memory on a device through calls to 
cudaMemcpy() from host code. 
‚Äì Its C equivalent is memcpy(). 
17

Parallel Computing
‚Ä¢ How do we run code in parallel on the device? 
add<<< 256, 1>>>(2, 7, device_c);
‚Äì Instead of executing add() once, execute 256 times 
in parallel 
‚Ä¢ <<<N,1>>>();
‚Äì The number ‚ÄúN‚Äù represents the number of parallel 
blocks (of threads) in which we would like the GPU 
to execute our kernel. 
‚Äì add<<< 256, 1>>>() can be thought as that the 
runtime creates 256 copies of the kernel and runs 
them in parallel. 
18

‚Ä¢ CUDA built-in variable: blockIdx
‚Äì CUDA runtime defines this variable.
‚Äì It contains the value of the block index for whichever block is currently 
running the device code. 
‚Äì CUDA C allows to define a group of blocks in one-, two- or threedimensions (version 2.x above). 
‚Ä¢ ùëÅ ‚àí specified as the number of parallel blocks per dimension
‚Äì A collection of parallel blocks is called a grid.
‚Äì This example specifies to the runtime system to allocate a onedimensional grid of ùëÅ blocks. 
‚Äì Threads will have different values for blockIdx.x, from 0 to ùëÅ ‚àí 1.
‚Äì ùëÅ ‚â§ 65,535 ‚àí a hardware-imposed limit (ùëÅ ‚â§ 2
31
-1 from version 3.x 
and above). 
‚Ä¢ if(tid< ùëÅ)
‚Äì Avoid potential bugs ‚Äì what if # threads requested is greater than ùëÅ?
21

Combining Blocks and Threads
‚Ä¢ Hardwire limits the number of blocks in a single 
launch to 65,535. 
‚Ä¢ Hardwire also limits the number of threads per 
block with which we can launch a kernel. 
‚Äì For many GPUs, maxThreadsPerBlock = 512 (or 1024, 
version 2.x above). 
‚Ä¢ Blocks and threads are often combined. 
23

To parallelize a for loop:
for(int i=0; i < 1000000; i++) {a[i]=x[i];}
‚Ä¢ In block/thread, we would like to have a single 
block/1000000 thread (ùëñ = 0,ùëó = 0, ‚Ä¶ , 999999) 
kernels containing: a[thread_index] = 
x[thread_index];
‚Ä¢ In real implementation, the exact same kernel is 
called blocks √ó threads times with the block and 
thread indices changing. 
‚Äì To use more than one multiprocessor, say ùëñ = 0, . . , 19,ùëó
= 0, ‚Ä¶ , 49 and kernel: 
a[block_index+thread_index]=x[block_index+thread_index];
24

‚Ä¢ Vector addition to use both blocks and threads
‚Äì We no longer simply use either blockIdx.x or 
threadIdx.x
‚Äì Consider indexing an array with one element per 
thread 
‚Äì We also use 8 threads per block. 
25
1. With ‚ÄúM‚Äù threads/block a unique index for each thread is given by:
int index = threadIdx.x + blockIdx.x*M; 
2. Use the built-in variable blockDim.x for threads/block
int index = threadIdx.x + blockIdx.x*blockDim.x;

28
‚Ä¢ We can not assume threads will complete in the order they are indexed.
‚Ä¢ We can not assume blocks will complete in the order they are labeled. 
‚Ä¢ To deal with data/task dependency:
‚Ä¢ Use synchronization: __syncthreads();
‚Ä¢ Split into kernels and call consecutively from C
‚Ä¢ Shared memory model: do not write to same memory location from different 
threads

Review: CUDA Programming Model
‚Ä¢ A CUDA program consists of code to be run on the 
host, i.e. the CPU, and the code to be run on the 
device, i.e. the GPU.
‚Äì Device has its own DRAM
‚Äì Device runs many threads in parallel
‚Ä¢ A function that is called by the host to execute on the 
device is called a kernel.
‚Äì Kernels run on many threads which realize data parallel 
portion of an application 
‚Ä¢ Threads in an application are grouped into blocks. The 
entirety of blocks is called the grid of that application.
29

30
‚Ä¢ Integrated host+device app C program
‚Äì Serial or modestly parallel parts in host C code
‚Äì Highly parallel parts in device SIMD kernel C code
Serial Code (host)
. . .
. . .
Parallel Kernel (device)
KernelA<<< nBlk, nTid >>>(args);
Serial Code (host)
Parallel Kernel (device)
KernelB<<< nBlk, nTid >>>(args);
¬© David Kirk/NVIDIA and Wen-mei W. Hwu, 2007-2009
ECE 498AL Spring 2010, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign

Host
Kernel 1
Kernel 2
Device
Grid 1
Block
(0, 0)
Block
(1, 0)
Block
(0, 1)
Block
(1, 1)
Grid 2
Courtesy: NDVIA
Figure 3.2. An Example of CUDA Thread Org
Block (1, 1)
Thread
(0,1,0)
Thread
(1,1,0)
Thread
(2,1,0)
Thread
(3,1,0)
Thread
(0,0,0)
Thread
(1,0,0)
Thread
(2,0,0)
Thread
(3,0,0)
(0,0,1) (1,0,1) (2,0,1) (3,0,1)
Thread Batching
‚Ä¢ A kernel is executed as a grid of 
thread blocks
‚Ä¢ A thread block is a batch of 
threads that can cooperate.
‚Ä¢ Each thread uses ID to decide 
what data to work on ‚Äì Block ID: 1D or 2D (or 
3D from 
version 2.x)
‚Äì Thread ID: 1D, 2D or 3D
‚Ä¢ Threads within a block 
coordinate by shared memory, 
atomic operations and barrier 
synchronization.
‚Ä¢ Threads in different blocks can 
not cooperate.
‚Ä¢ Convenient for solving PDEs on 
grid cells. 
32

CUDA Memory Model
33
‚Ä¢ Global memory
‚Äì Main means of 
communicating 
R/W Data 
between host and 
device
‚Äì Contents visible to 
all threads
‚Äì Long latency 
access
Grid
Global Memory
Block (0, 0)
Shared Memory
Thread (0, 0)
Registers
Thread (1, 0)
Registers
Block (1, 0)
Shared Memory
Thread (0, 0)
Registers
Thread (1, 0)
Registers
Host

Host-Device Data Transfer
35
‚Ä¢ cudaMemcpy(void *dst, const void *src, size_t count, enum cudaMemcpyKind
kind)
‚Äì memory data transfer
‚Äì Requires four parameters
‚Ä¢ Pointer to destination 
‚Ä¢ Pointer to source
‚Ä¢ Number of bytes copied
‚Ä¢ Type of transfer 
‚Äì Host to Host
‚Äì Host to Device
‚Äì Device to Host
‚Äì Device to Device
‚Ä¢ Asynchronous transfer
‚Ä¢ Example: 
‚Äì Transfer a 64 * 64 single precision float array
‚Äì M is in host memory and Md is in device memory
‚Äì cudaMemcpyHostToDevice and cudaMemcpyDeviceToHost are 
symbolic constants
cudaMemcpy(Md, M, size, cudaMemcpyHostToDevice);
cudaMemcpy(M, Md, size, cudaMemcpyDeviceToHost);

Device Memory Allocation ‚Äì MultiD Case
‚Ä¢ Linear memory can also be allocated through 
cudaMallocPitch() and cudaMalloc3D(). 
‚Äì Recommended for allocations of 2D or 3D arrays as it 
makes sure that the allocation is appropriately padded 
to meet the alignment requirements imposed by the 
device. 
‚Äì It ensures best performance when accessing the row 
addresses or performing copies between 2D arrays 
and other regions of device memory (using the 
cudaMemcpy2D() and cudaMemcpy3D() functions)
‚Äì The returned pitch (or stride) must be used to access 
array elements. 
36

cudaError_t cudaMallocPitch(void **devPtr, size_t *pitch, size_t width, 
size_t height)
‚Äì Allocates at least width (in bytes) * height bytes of linear 
memory on the device and returns in *devPtr a pointer to the 
allocated memory. The function may pad the allocation to ensure 
that corresponding pointers in any given row will continue to 
meet the alignment requirements for coalescing as the address is 
updated from row to row. The pitch returned in *pitch by 
cudaMallocPitch() is the width in bytes of the allocation.
‚Äì Parameters:
 devPtr - Pointer to allocated pitched device memory
 pitch - Pitch for allocation
 width - Requested pitched allocation width (in bytes)
 height - Requested pitched allocation height
‚Äì Returns: cudaSuccess, cudaErrorMemoryAllocation
‚Äì Given the row and column of an array element of type T, the 
address is computed as: 
 T* pElement = (T*)((char*)BaseAddress + Row * pitch) + Column;
37

CUDA Function Declarations
39
‚Ä¢ __global__ defines a kernel function
‚Äì Must return void
‚Äì Example: __global__ void KernelFunc()
‚Äì Executed on the device, only callable from the 
host
‚Ä¢ __device__ defines a function called by kernels. 
‚Ä¢ Example: __device__ float DeviceFunc()
‚Ä¢ Executed on the device, only callable from the 
device
‚Ä¢ __host__ defines a function running on the host
‚Ä¢ Example: __host__ float HostFunc()
‚Ä¢ Executed on the host, only callable from 
the host

‚Ä¢ __device__ functions cannot have their 
address taken
‚Ä¢ For functions executed on the device:
‚Äì No recursion
‚Äì No static variable declarations inside the function
‚Äì No variable number of arguments
40

Lecture 11: Programming on GPUs 
(Part 2)
42

Thread Creation
‚Ä¢ Threads are created when program calls kernel 
functions.
‚Ä¢ A kernel function must be called with an execution 
configuration:
__global__ void KernelFunc(...);
dim3 DimGrid(100, 50); // 5000 thread blocks 
dim3 DimBlock(4, 8, 8); // 256 threads per block 
size_t SharedMemBytes = 64; // 64 bytes of shared memory
KernelFunc<<< DimGrid, DimBlock, SharedMemBytes
>>>(...);
‚Ä¢ Any call to a kernel function is asynchronous from 
CUDA 1.0 on, explicit synch needed for blocking
43
dim3 is a special CUDA datatype with 3 components .x, .y, .z each initialized to 1.

Host
Kernel 
1
Kernel 
2
Device
Grid 1
Block
(0, 0)
Block
(1, 0)
Block
(0, 1)
Block
(1, 1)
Grid 2
Courtesy: NDVIA
Figure 3.2. An Example of CUDA Thread Org
Block (1, 1)
Thread
(0,1,0)

(1,1,0)
Thread
(2,1,0)
Thread
(3,1,0)
Thread
(0,0,0)
Thread
(1,0,0)
Thread
(2,0,0)
Thread
(3,0,0)
(0,0,1) (1,0,1) (2,0,1) (3,0,1)
‚Ä¢ A collection of blocks from a grid (1D, 2D 
or 3D)
‚Äì Built-in variable gridDim specifies the size 
(or dimension) of the grid.
‚Äì Each copy of the kernel can determine 
which block it is executing with the built-in 
variable blockIdx. 
‚Ä¢ Threads in a block are arranged in 1D, 2D, 
or 3D arrays. 
‚Äì Built-in variable blockDim specifies the 
size (or dimensions) of block.
‚Äì threadIdx index (or 2D/3D indices) thread 
within a block
‚Äì maxThreadsPerBlock: The limit is 512 
threads per block
44
kernel_routine<<<gridDim, blockDim>>>(args);

GPU SUMs of a Long Vector
‚Ä¢ Assume 65,535*512 >> N > 512, so we need to launch 
threads across multiple blocks. 
‚Ä¢ Let‚Äôs use 128 threads per block. We need N/128 blocks.
‚Äì N/128 is integer division. If N were < 128, N/128 would be 0.
‚Äì Actually compute (N+127)/128 blocks.
‚Ä¢ add <<<(N+127)/128, 128>>>(dev_a, dev_b, dev_c);
47
#define N 4000
__global__ void add(int *a, int *b, int *c){
 int tid = threadIdx.x + blockDim.x*blockIdx.x; // handle the data at this index
 if(tid < N) c[tid] = a[tid] + b[tid]; // launch too many treads when N is not exact 
} // multiple of 128

Matrix Multiplication
‚Ä¢ Demonstrate basic features of memory and 
thread management in CUDA programs
‚Äì Leave shared memory usage until later
‚Äì Local, register usage
‚Äì Thread ID usage
‚Äì Memory data transfer API between host and device
‚Äì Assume square matrix for simplicity
52

‚Ä¢ ùëÉ = ùëÄ √ó ùëÅ of size WIDTH√óWIDTH
‚Ä¢ Without blocking:
‚Äì One thread handles one element of ùëÉ
‚Äì M and N are loaded WIDTH times from 
global memory
53
M
N
P

59
‚Ä¢ One Block of threads compute 
matrix Pd
‚Äì Each thread computes one 
element of Pd
‚Ä¢ Each thread
‚Äì Loads a row of matrix Md
‚Äì Loads a column of matrix Nd
‚Äì Perform one multiply and 
addition for each pair of Md and 
Nd elements
‚Äì Compute to off-chip memory 
access ratio close to 1:1 (not very 
high)
‚Ä¢ Size of matrix limited by the 
number of threads allowed in a 
thread block
Grid 1
Block 1
3 2 5 4
2
4
2
6
48
Thread
(2, 2)
 WIDTH
Md Pd
Nd

‚Ä¢ ùëÉ = ùëÄ √ó ùëÅ of size WIDTH√óWIDTH
‚Ä¢ With blocking:
‚Äì One thread block handles one 
BLOCK_SIZE √ó BLOCK_SIZE (or 
TILE_WIDTH √ó TILE_WIDTH) submatrix (tile) ùëÉùëëùë†ùë¢ùëè of ùëÉ
‚Ä¢ Block size equal tile size
‚Ä¢ Each thread calculates one element
‚Äì Genrate a 2D grid of 
(WIDTH/TILE_WIDTH)2 blocks
‚Äì Linear memory allocation for all 
matrices is used
60

Multithreading
‚Ä¢ Cores in a streaming multiprocessor (SM) are Single 
Instruction Multiple Threads (SIMT) cores:
‚Äì Maximum number of threads in a block depends on the 
compute capability (1024 on Fermi)
‚Ä¢ all cores execute the same instructions simultaneously, but with 
different data.
‚Äì GPU multiprocessor creates, manages, schedules and executes 
threads in warps of 32*
‚Ä¢ minimum of 32 threads all doing the same thing at (almost) the same 
time (Warp executes one common instruction at a time).
‚Ä¢ no ‚Äúcontext switching‚Äù; each thread has its own registers, which limits 
the number of active threads
‚Ä¢ Threads are allowed to branch, but branches are serialized
‚Äì threads on each SM execute in groups of 32 called ‚Äúwarps‚Äù
‚Äì execution alternates between ‚Äúactive‚Äù warps, with warps 
becoming temporarily ‚Äúinactive‚Äù when waiting for data
63

‚Ä¢ Suppose we have 1000 blocks, and each one has 128 
threads ‚Äì how does it get executed?
‚Ä¢ On current Fermi hardware, would probably get 8 blocks 
running at the same time on each SM, and each block has 
4 warps =) 32 warps running on each SM
‚Ä¢ Each clock tick, SM warp scheduler decides which warp to 
execute next, choosing from those not waiting for
‚Äì data coming from device memory (memory latency)
‚Äì completion of earlier instructions (pipeline delay)
‚Ä¢ Programmer doesn‚Äôt have to worry about this level of 
detail (can always do profiling later), just make sure there 
are lots of threads / warps
65

Spatial Locality
__global__ void good_kernel(float *x)
{
 int tid = threadIdx.x + blockDim.x*blockIdx.x;
 x[tid] = threadIdx.x;
}
‚Ä¢ 32 threads in a warp address neighboring elements of array 
x.
‚Ä¢ If the data is correctly ‚Äúaligned‚Äù so that x[0] is at the 
beginning of a cache line, then x[0]-x[31] will be in the 
same cache line.
‚Äì Cache line is the basic unit of data transfer, 128 bytes cache line 
(32 floats or 16 doubles). 
‚Ä¢ Good spatial locality.
66

Software View
At the top level, we have a master process which runs on the 
CPU and performs the following steps:
1. initializes card
2. allocates memory in host and on device
‚Äì cudaMalloc(),‚Ä¶
3. copies data from host to device memory
‚Äì cudaMemcpy(‚Ä¶, cudaMemcpyHostToDevice);
4. launches multiple instances of execution ‚Äúkernel‚Äù on device
‚Äì kernel_routine<<<gridDim, blockDim>>>(args);
5. copies data from device memory to host
‚Äì cudaMemcpy(‚Ä¶, cudaMemcpyDeviceToHost);
6. repeats 3-5 as needed
7. de-allocates all memory and terminates
‚Äì cudaFree()
68

Software View
At a lower level, within the GPU:
1. each instance of the execution kernel executes on an SM
2. if the number of instances exceeds the number of SMs, then more than one 
will run at a time on each SM if there are enough registers and shared 
memory, and the others will wait in a queue and execute later
3. all threads within one instance can access local shared memory but can‚Äôt 
see what the other instances are doing (even if they are on the same SM)
4. there are no guarantees on the order in which the instances execute
69

CUDA Memories
‚Ä¢ Each thread can:
‚Äì Read/write per-thread registers 
‚Äì Read/write per-thread local 
memory
‚Äì Read/write per-block shared 
memory
‚Äì Read/write per-grid global 
memory
‚Äì Read/only per-grid constant 
memory
70
Grid
Global Memory
Block (0, 0)
Shared Memory
Thread (0, 0)
Registers
Thread (1, 0)
Registers
Block (1, 0)
Shared Memory
Thread (0, 0)
Registers
Thread (1, 0)
Registers
Host
Constant Memory
Local Memory
‚Ä¢ Usually used when one runs out of SM 
resources 
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúLocal‚Äù because each thread has its own 
private area
‚Ä¢ Not really a ‚Äúmemory‚Äù ‚Äì bytes are stored in 
global memory
‚Ä¢ Stores are cached in L1

Fermi Memory Hierarchy
NVIDIA 2011 71

Access Times
72
‚Ä¢ Register ‚Äì dedicated HW ‚Äì single cycle
‚Ä¢ Shared Memory ‚Äì dedicated HW ‚Äì single cycle
‚Ä¢ Local Memory ‚Äì DRAM ‚Äì slow 
‚Ä¢ Global Memory ‚Äì DRAM ‚Äì slow
‚Ä¢ Constant Memory ‚Äì DRAM, cached, 
1‚Ä¶10s ‚Ä¶ 100s of cycles, depending on cache locality
‚Ä¢ Texture Memory ‚Äì DRAM, cached, 
1‚Ä¶10s ‚Ä¶ 100s of cycles, depending on cache locality
‚Ä¢ Instruction Memory (invisible) ‚Äì DRAM, cached

Variable Types
‚Ä¢ the __device__ indicates this is a global variable in the 
GPU
‚Äì the variable can be read and modified by any kernel
‚Äì its lifetime is the lifetime of the whole application
‚Äì can also declare arrays of fixed size
‚Äì can read/write by host code using standard cudaMemcpy
‚Ä¢ __device__ is optional when used with __local__, 
__shared__, or __constant__
73
Variable declaration Memory Scope Lifetime
__device__ __local__ int LocalVar; local thread thread
__device__ __shared__ int SharedVar; shared block block
__device__ int GlobalVar; global grid application
__device__ __constant__ int ConstantVar; constant grid application

Shared Memory
__shared__ int x_dim;
__shared__ float x[128];
‚Ä¢ declares data to be shared between all of the 
threads in the thread block ‚Äì any thread can set its 
value, or read it.
‚Ä¢ Advantages of using shared memory
‚Äì essential for operations requiring communication 
between threads 
‚Äì useful for data re-use
‚Äì alternative to local arrays in device memory
‚Äì reduces use of registers when a variable has same value 
for all threads
76

Cooperating Threads
77
1D Stencil
‚Ä¢ Consider applying a 1D stencil to a 1D array of 
elements
‚Äì Each output element is the sum of input elements 
within a radius
‚Äì If radius = 3, then each output element is the sum of 
7 input elements
‚Äì Assume we use 1D block grid and 1D block of 
threads

Implementing within a Block
‚Ä¢ Each thread processes one output element
‚Äì blockDim.x elements per block
‚Ä¢ Input elements are read several times
‚Äì With radius 3, each input element is read 7 times
78

Sharing Data Between Threads
‚Ä¢ Within a block, threads share data by shared 
memory
‚Ä¢ Extremely fast on-chip memory, usermanaged
‚Ä¢ Declare using __shared__, allocated per block
‚Ä¢ Data is not visible to threads in other blocks
79

Implementation
‚Ä¢ Cache data in shared memory
‚Äì Read (blockDim.x + 2*radius) input elements from 
device global memory to shared memory
‚Äì Compute blockDim.x output elements
‚Äì Write blockDim.x output elements to global 
memory
80

Data Race
‚Ä¢ The stencil example will not work
‚Ä¢ Suppose thread 15 reads the halo before 
thread 0 has fetch it
82

void __syncthreads()
‚Ä¢ Synchronizes all threads within a block 
‚Äì Used to prevent data races
‚Ä¢ All threads must reach the barrier
‚Äì In conditional code, the condition must be 
uniform across the block
83

‚Ä¢ If a thread block has more than one warp, it‚Äôs not pre-determined 
when each warp will execute its instructions ‚Äì warp 1 could be 
many instructions ahead of warp 2, or well behind.
‚Ä¢ Consequently, almost always need thread synchronization to ensure 
correct use of shared memory.
‚Ä¢ Instruction
‚Äì __syncthreads();
‚Ä¢ inserts a ‚Äúbarrier‚Äù; no thread/warp is allowed to proceed beyond 
this point until the rest have reached it
‚Ä¢ Total size of shared memory is specified by an optional third 
arguments when launching the kernel:
‚Äì kernel<<<blocks,threads,shared_bytes>>>(...)
85

Active Blocks per SM
‚Ä¢ Each block require certain resources:
‚Äì threads
‚Äì registers (registers per thread √ó number of threads)
‚Äì shared memory (static + dynamic)
‚Ä¢ Together these decide how many blocks can be run 
simultaneously on each SM ‚Äì up to a maximum of 8 blocks
‚Ä¢ General advice:
‚Äì number of active threads depends on number of registers each 
needs
‚Äì good to have at least 2-4 active blocks, each with at least 128 
threads
‚Äì smaller number of blocks when each needs lots of shared 
memory
‚Äì larger number of blocks when they don‚Äôt need shared memory
‚Äì On Fermi card:
‚Ä¢ maybe 2 big blocks (512 threads) if each needs a lot of shared 
memory
‚Ä¢ maybe 6 smaller blocks (256 threads) if no shared memory needed
‚Ä¢ or 4 small blocks (128 threads) if each thread needs lots of registers 86

‚Ä¢ Global memory resides in device memory (DRAM) - much slower access than 
shared memory
‚Ä¢ So, a profitable way of performing computation on the device is to tile data to 
take advantage of fast shared memory:
‚Äì Partition data into subsets that fit into shared memory
‚Äì Handle each data subset with one thread block by:
‚Ä¢ Loading the subset from global memory to shared memory, using multiple threads to exploit 
memory-level parallelism
‚Ä¢ Performing the computation on the subset from shared memory; each thread can efficiently 
multi-pass over any data element
‚Ä¢ Copying results from shared memory to global memory
‚Ä¢ Constant memory also resides in device memory (DRAM) - much slower access 
than shared memory
‚Äì But‚Ä¶ cached!
‚Äì Highly efficient access for read-only data
‚Ä¢ Carefully divide data according to access patterns
‚Äì R/Only ÔÉ† constant memory (very fast if in cache)
‚Äì R/W shared within Block ÔÉ† shared memory (very fast)
‚Äì R/W within each thread ÔÉ† registers (very fast)
‚Äì R/W inputs/results ÔÉ† global memory (very slow)
87

Shared Memory to Reuse Global Memory Data

and have several 
threads use the local 
version to reduce the 
memory bandwidth

time

‚Ä¢ Each thread block should have many threads
‚Äì TILE_WIDTH of 16 gives 16*16 = 256 threads
‚Ä¢ There should be many thread blocks
‚Äì A 1024*1024 Pd gives 64*64 = 4096 Thread Blocks
‚Ä¢ Each thread block perform 2*256 = 512 float 
loads from global memory for 256 * (2*16) = 
8,192 mul/add operations. 
‚Äì Memory bandwidth no longer a limiting factor
97

Performance on G80
‚Ä¢ Each SM in G80 has 16KB shared memory
‚Äì SM size is implementation dependent!
‚Äì For TILE_WIDTH = 16, each thread block uses 2*256*4B = 2KB of shared memory. 
‚Äì Can potentially have up to 8 Thread Blocks actively executing 
‚Ä¢ This allows up to 8*512 = 4,096 pending loads. (2 per thread, 256 threads per block)
‚Äì The next TILE_WIDTH 32 would lead to 2*32*32*4B= 8KB shared memory usage per 
thread block, allowing only up to two thread blocks active at the same time
‚Ä¢ Using 16x16 tiling, we reduce the accesses to the global memory by a factor 
of 16
‚Äì The 86.4B/s bandwidth can now support (86.4/4)*16 = 347.6 GFLOPS

2D Laplace Solver Using CUDA
‚Ä¢ each thread responsible for one grid point
‚Ä¢ each block of threads responsible for a block 
of the grid
‚Ä¢ conceptually very similar to data partitioning 
in MPI distributed-memory implementations, 
but much simpler
102

‚Ä¢ Each block of threads processes one of these grid blocks, 
reading in old values and computing new values.
105

Assumptions:
‚Ä¢ I is a multiple of blockDim.x
‚Ä¢ J is a multiple of blockDim.y
grid breaks up perfectly into blocks
‚Ä¢ I is a multiple of 32
Can remove these assumptions by
‚Ä¢ testing if i, j are within grid
‚Ä¢ padding the array in x to make it a multiple of 32, so 
each row starts at the beginning of a cache line ‚Äì this 
uses a special routine cudaMallocPitch
107

Lecture 11: Programming on GPUs 
(Part 3)
108

Control Flow and Synchronization
‚Ä¢ Warp divergence ‚Äì different threads in a warp need to do 
different things
if(x< 0.0)
 z = x ‚Äì 2.0;
Else 
 z = sqrt(x);
‚Ä¢ CUDA has predicated instructions which are carried out only if a 
logical flag is true.
‚Äì All threads compute the logical predicate and two predicated 
instructions
P= (x < 0.0);
p: z = x-2.0; // single instruction
!p: z = sqrt(x); 
‚Ä¢ all threads execute both conditional branches, so execution cost 
is sum of both branches
‚Äì potentially large loss of performance
109

Synchronization
_syncthreads()
‚Ä¢ forms a barrier ‚Äì all threads wait until every 
one has reached this point.
‚Ä¢ When writing conditional code, must be 
careful to make sure that all threads do reach 
the __syncthreads(). Otherwise, can end up in 
deadlock
110

Hybrid MPI/CUDA
1. One MPI process per GPU
‚Äì GPU handling is straight forward
‚Äì Wastes the other cores of the processor
2. Many MPI processes per GPU, only one uses it
‚Äì Poses difficult load balancing problems
3. Many MPI processes share a GPU
‚Äì Two processes cannot share the same GPU context, 
per process memory on GPU
‚Äì Sharing may not always be possible
‚Ä¢ Limited memory on GPU
‚Ä¢ If GPUs are in exclusive mode
111

‚Ä¢ CUDA will be: 
‚Äì Doing the computational heavy lifting 
‚Äì Dictating your algorithm & parallel 
layout (data parallel) 
‚Ä¢ Therefore: 
‚Äì Design CUDA portions first 
‚Äì Use MPI to move work to each node
112

114
Process #1
Process #2
cudaSetDevice(0)
cudaSetDevice(1)
CUDA
kernel
CUDA
kernel

Compiling
‚Ä¢ Kernel, kernel invocation, cudaMalloc, are all best 
off in a .cu file somewhere 
‚Ä¢ MPI calls should be in .c files 
‚Ä¢ nvcc processes .cu files to generate objective files
‚Ä¢ mpicc/mpicxx processes .c/.cpp files to generate 
objective files
‚Ä¢ If we need to call CUDA kernels from within an 
MPI task, we can wrap the appropriate CUDAcompiled functions with the ‚Äúextern‚Äù keyword.
115

CUDA RNG
‚Ä¢ RNG: random number generator
‚Ä¢ CURAND
‚Äì NVIDIA's library for random number generation in 
CUDA
‚Äì CURAND can be called from the host and the device
‚Äì CURAND Host API provides functions callable on the 
host to generate random data in GPU global memory
‚Äì Can create multiple pseudorandom generators using 
different algorithms
116

PI Calculation
‚Ä¢ Disk: ùëÜ1 = ùúãùëü
2
‚Ä¢ Square: ùëÜ2 = 4ùëü
2

4ùëÜ1
ùëÜ2
119

‚Ä¢ To generate random numbers on the GPU 
memory: 
1. Include curand_kernel.h
2. Allocate a memory space on device to store 
CURAND state.
3. Initialize the state with a ‚Äúseed‚Äù
4. Generate random number sequences
120

‚Ä¢ __device__ void curand_init (unsigned long long seed, unsigned long long
sequence, unsigned long long offset, curandState *state)
‚Äì The curand_init() function sets up an initial state allocated by the caller. thread will use its own 
curandState to generate its own random number sequence
‚Ä¢ __device__ float curand_uniform (curandState *state)
‚Äì This function returns a sequence of pseudorandom floats uniformly distributed between 0.0 and 
1.0
‚Ä¢ __device__ float curand_normal (curandState *state)
‚Äì This function returns a single normally distributed float with mean 0.0 and standard deviation 
1.0.
123

‚Ä¢ Generate many randomly 
distributed points within the 
square
‚Ä¢ The area of the circle can be 
approximately obtained from 
the ratio of points inside of 
the circle and the total 
number of points.
124

Architecture, S. Tariq, NVIDIA Corporation
